data.title: Schoo; Field Trip
data.text: Went here for my son's school Fied Trip, and really enjoyed it.  Excellent docent showed us around and told very interesting stories about the founders of the Livermore Tri Valley.  Small, but packed with interesting artifacts and history of the valley.

data.title: Classic small-town museum
data.text:
Small, very manageable-size museum with a focus on local history, and featuring occasional special exhibits.
My highest recommendation: after visiting this museum with her class, my granddaughter begged me to take her again, and she especially enjoyed the interactive exhibits.

data.title: Ghosts and more
data.text: Very fun time attending the annual ghost tour.  Fun and entertaining evening. All of the ghosts were very nice.  Interesting history of how Pleasanton was in the past too.

data.title: a wonderful local museum
data.text: Almost free, leave a donation at the door upon enteing,  its a well done local history museum w a small gift shop, you wont be disappointed.

data.title: Small museum
data.text: Has rotating exhibits and is typical museum for most small towns. It is in downtown and many places to visit and shop around area. Would spend about 30 minutes and then can move on to other downtown activities. Some info about area and not much else. Does have archive section.

data.title: Wonderful Place
data.text: Right in the very heart of downtown is this little jewel with many wonderful displays about days gone by.  Friendly staff and rexing too.  The change the venue and keep history fresh!

data.title: Well, nice building but not much there.
data.text: Great location, nice building but they need to build up what they are exhibiting. Maybe the venue would be best suited for special traveling exhibits or small local shows that would attract very specialized visitors.

data.title: If you want to know Pleasanton
data.text: It is a very small museum. Do not expect to find lot of information inside. It just has a few bits and pieces about Pleasanton - its history and its residents. There is no entry fee, donation is more than welcome.

data.title: A very good local history museum.
data.text: If you want to learn about local Pleasanton History, this is the place to come, for all ages.  It has interesting artifacts and pictures from the time of the Alone Indians through the gold rush. They show an interesting history based on facts that shows the street it is on was once part of Mexico, they will even show you the place down the street that once only ran movies in Spanish.  It is a very cool small museum, who fills you in on all the founders of the City and how Pleasanton came to be the city it is today.

data.title: Rotating traveling exhibits enhance this museum
data.text: There is one large room static display of Pleasanton artifacts and a smaller room for traveling exhibits.   The rotating exhibits last about three months each and become the main draw for repeat visits.

data.title: Great Way to Spend an Hour
data.text: The Museum on Main is always a great place to spend an hour or so. The displays change often and are always well done and interesting. There always employees to answer questions and explain displays

data.title: A breath of history.
data.text: A surprising free venue on a stroll through Pleasanton. Lovely docents with lots of information about the roots of Pleasanton and the tri-valley. Interesting displays..and a clean bathroom! Happy to see places like this are still available, employing people interested in history and educating the public.

data.title: Wonderful Old Pleasanton info
data.text: Extremely well versed docents eager too share. Very interesting scenes of old TriValley area, especially Pleasanton. Well worth your time...bring the kids.

data.title: Pleasanton's Little Gem
data.text: Although we probably pass the Museum on Main at least once a week, as we drive down Main Street, or go to the Farmers Market, most people most likely have not gone through the doors. There are changing exhibits, even a recent visiting Smithsonian exhibit on immigration. The museum has a lot to offer on the history of Pleasanton, and other exhibits, and lectures.  The plaza in front of the museum has tiles of family names of people who made donations. It's fun to look through the names to see local names you might recognize.

data.title: Love this local bit of history!
data.text: Always like to stop by here when they have a new exhibit!  The gift shop has a lot of nice local history items and souvenirs of the Pleasanton/Tri-Valley area.

data.title: Wow!  Cool way to learn about local history.
data.text: Half Art gallery, Half Museum, some real nuggets in this place.  The exhibits in the small museum range from key historical maps, photos and artifacts, to actual objects you can touch and feel.  I learned a lot about Pleasanton (named after a Civil War General, there is a photo of him alongside George A. Custer).  Good Amador Valley, Dublin and Livermore historical references as well.  This is yet another slower, quieter way to spend some time enjoying and learning the area.  Very Highly recommended for new visitors and long time residents alike.

data.title: Nice Local Museum
data.text: It is a small museum staffed by very friendly and very dedicated staff and volunteers.  The exhibits change pretty often so there is often something new.  The permanent exhibit highlights Pleasanton's development.

data.title: Lovely museum
data.text: We had a little time to spare so we went to the little Pleasanton museum. Very delightful! Lots of material in the little house, but interesting. It won't take you very long to go through  all it. But I think we'll worth it as it gave me a great overview of the origins of this town.

data.title: Fun stop with great people
data.text:
A small museum, it only takes an hour to see.  This is for local history buffs.  Lots of fun stories about people who founded and lived there.  
It has is small gift shop, but the real fun are the volunteers .  Full of fun and very helpful. 
Look for the parking lot behind the building.

data.title: Best little museum in California
data.text:
Want to know who founded Pleasanton?  Want to know how the streets were named for?  Want to know who the original families were that founded our city?

Take an hour and visit this quaint little museum.  The best part of the museum - the docents working  the facility.  Their knowledge of Pleasanton and the surrounding area is only exceeded by their enthusiasm.

I personally think every high school freshman should be required to come here and learn about the city they live in.

Thank you staff of your time and information.
